newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan president signs bill clipping his powers.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan president signs bill clipping his powers.

text.p: Pakistani President Farooq Leghari has signed a constitutional amendment bill that clips his powers to sack governments and appoint military chiefs and provincial governors, a spokesman for him said on Friday.
The spokesman told Reuters the president had signed the bill on Thursday.
The Senate (upper house) and the National Assembly (lower house) unanimously passed the bill on Tuesday, giving Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif the upper hand in Pakistan's power structure.

The bill has undone clauses of the Eighth Amendment, a relic from the military rule of late president General Mohammad Zia-ul-Haq from 1977 to 1988, and used by three presidents to sack four prime ministers in the past eight years.

Under the amendments, a dissolution of the National Assembly and subsequent sacking of a prime minister, and the appointment of armed forces chiefs and provincial governors by the president, will be subject to binding prime ministerial advice.
With presidential assent the amendment bill has become law with effect from Thursday, legal sources said.
